http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Theatre Appreciation is a one-semester course in which students will develop fundamental theatre skills through academic study. Students will develop an understanding of basic theatre skills and the history of the theatre, analyze and evaluate artistic work, and discover connections between theatrical works and societal, cultural, and historical contexts. The Standards for Accreditation require schools to offer a one-half unit of survey of fine arts OR one-half unit of advanced art or advanced music. Theatre Appreciation may be used to fulfill this requirement. Theatre Appreciation also fulfills the one-half unit of fine arts required for graduation. Arkansas Department of Education approval is not required for Theatre Appreciation.
Creating
Students will generate and conceptualize artistic ideas and work.
Differentiate between theatre as an art form and dramatic play
Explore the concept of imaginary environments
Explore the collaborative nature of theatre
Students will organize and develop artistic ideas and work.

Differentiate between different onstage and offstage theatrical positions
  • actor
  • director
  • designer
  • producer
  • playwright
  • technician
  • stage manager
Examine the impact of different types of theatre spaces
Identify theatrical conventions in a devised or scripted drama/theatre work

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., blackout represents passing of time, set with three walls represents an entire room, soliloquy represents character's internal monologue

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Students will refine and complete artistic work.
Establish empathy for characters in a devised or scripted drama/theatre work
Examine self and peer evaluations of artistic work
Performing/Presenting
Students will analyze, interpret, and select artistic work for presentation.

Analyze a scripted drama/theatre work of literary merit
  • character
  • given circumstances
  • mood
  • plot structure
  • theme
Characterize various genres of plays
Analyze scripts to determine technical requirements
Interpret characters and technical elements based on research from multiple sources of information

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., script, print resources, web resources, film, video

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Recognize a character's objectives and tactics

Analyze the elements of drama in a scripted drama/theatre work
  • character
  • language
  • plot
  • rhythm
  • spectacle
  • theme
Students will develop and refine artistic work for presentation.
Investigate physical, vocal, and psychological choices that lead to a believable, authentic, and relevant performance of a drama/theatre work

Explore the development of dramatic/theatrical skills and techniques through the rehearsal process
  • table work
  • blocking
  • working rehearsals
  • tech rehearsals
  • dress rehearsals
  • performance

Examine character development through steps of the acting process
  • analysis
  • research
  • vocal/movement choices
  • character choices
  • rehearsal
Discover the characteristics of a strong and versatile stage voice

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g. pitch, volume, breath support, diction

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Research technical elements to refine a presentation for increased impact
Students will convey meaning through the presentation of artistic work.
Articulate the meaning of a devised or scripted drama/theatre work
Responding
Students will perceive and analyze artistic work.
Analyze the consequences of a character's decisions and actions
Discuss the contribution of technical elements to the effectiveness of a production
Discuss dramatic elements of an observed drama/theatre work using basic theatre terminology
Respond appropriately to a theatrical experience as an audience member
Students will interpret intent and meaning in artistic work.
Compare emotional responses evoked by a variety of genres
Discuss the impact of technical design choices on the mood and meaning of a scripted drama/theatre work
Students will apply criteria to evaluate artistic work.
Develop criteria using basic theatre terminology to evaluate artistic work

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., self, peer, stage, film, television

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Distinguish between personal preferences and artistic merit of a drama/theatre work
Connecting
Students will synthesize and relate knowledge and personal experiences to make art.
Analyze the impact of personal experience on the creation of drama/theatre work
Describe, based on research, the use of acting theories (e.g., internal, external, integrated, method) to impact the creation of drama/theatre work
Students will relate artistic ideas and works with societal, cultural, and historical context to deepen understanding.
Research the societal, cultural, and historical contexts that lead to personal artistic choices
Explain the influence of cultural perspectives and theatrical conventions/practices on theatre art
Investigate the effect of theatre on people of various ages and cultures
Develop cultural sensitivity to the artistic work of others
Discuss the influence of community values and beliefs in the creation of drama/theatre work
Research significant periods in theatre history, utilizing technology
Compare the theatre experience to that of other art forms and media
Compare the creative processes used in various art forms

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., visual art, music, dance, film

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Describe the role of technology in the theatre
